item.title: Rhombus with Tor
item.description: a) Using the Tor Browser b) Using the Tor Daemon c) Tor as a Hidden Service The only privacy protocol that’s not enabled by default on Rhombus Desktop is the ability to hide your IP address using the Tor network. While it could eventually be enabled by default or through the Settings page, Tor currently needs to be activated manually to route your Rhombus Desktop connection through its network.

item.title: Running multiple wallets
item.description: Multiwallet setup Rhombus Desktop Rhombus Core Autostart multiwallet Rhombus Desktop Rhombus Core Linux You might want to create and use multiple wallets for different usage. The goal is to separate your finances, so they won’t mix up. This approach will also help you gain a bit more privacy (never linking all of your available funds).

item.title: Self-hosting RHOM payment processor
item.description: By hosting your own instance of Rhombus’s BTCPayServer, you can create your very own independent payment processor for both Rhombus and Bitcoin. item.title: Rhombus as Tor Hidden Service
item.description: Download Rhombus wallet Install Tor Define HS in Tor config Find your IP for HS Modify rhombus.conf Start wallet It also protects your machine from geolocation and its possible ugly consequences, and automatically sets you up for both incoming and outgoing connections, helping the Rhombus network. It is recommended to always run the Rhombus through Tor. This guide is written purely for Linux (specificaly Ubuntu-based distributions).

item.description: Basics Rhombus Transactions Balances Network Other resources Here are a few tips to keep you private as much as possible: Basics Never brag about how much RHOM or BTC you own, online or offline. item.title: Private markets
item.description: They are not accessible from the public interface of the Open Marketplace. The only way to access them is by entering their unique Market ID in the Rhombus Desktop client. The Market ID is only known to the person that initially generated the private market and to the people he shared it with. While private markets aren’t part of the first mainnet version of the Open Marketplace, they will be implemented during the Beta phase of development.
